NYSC OYO STAFF BIDS FAREWELL TO  RETIRED OFFICERS, CELEBRATES TRANSFERRED OFFICERS 

In a heartwarming celebration that embodied the spirit of camaraderie and appreciation, NYSC Oyo staff gathered to honor two esteemed colleagues: Mr. Mathew Adewuyi and Mrs. Kolade Justina who retired from service and  Staffers who were on posting to another formations of the NYSC Scheme. The event, put together by the Staff Welfare, NYSC Oyo was filled with warmth, nostalgia, and joy. It was a befitting tribute to the celebrants' commitment, dedication, doggedness and invaluable contributions to the NYSC Scheme over the years.

In his opening remarks, the State Coordinator, Mr. Kayode Ola Peters warmly welcomed all Members of Staff, the retirees and their families and friends, setting the tone for a memorable occasion.  He expressed profound gratitude to God for His mercy, protection, and blessings over their lives, noting that it is a thing of joy to start well and finish strong without recording any casaulty. 

While acknowledging and thanking the retirees for their invaluable contributions during their years in active service, Kayode stressed that the Scheme will reach out to them anytime to tap from their wealth of experience, recognizing the immense value they would bring to the organization even in retirement. 

In his welcome address, the Chairman of the Staff Welfare, Mr. Orioke Oluwaseun expressed gratitude to the State Coordinator for his support in making the event a reality. He congratulated the retirees for their successful disengagement from service and prayed that God will strengthen them the more and guide them through their future endeavours.

Members of Staff who gave goodwill messages described the retirees as dogged, committed, easygoing, and great mentors. Their colleagues praised their dedication, commitment, and passion for their work, which has left a lasting impact on the organization.

In their separate responses, the celebrants thanked the entire staff for the show of love and prayed that the good working relationship in the Scheme be sustained.

The highlight of the occasion was the presentation of cash gifts to the retirees and transferred Officers and group photographs. These gestures served as a token of appreciation for the retirees' years of service and commitment to the organization.

The National Youth Service Corps (NYSC) Lagos State Coordinator, Mrs. Christiana Salmwang, has advised corps members of the 2024 Batch B Stream II to leverage skills gained during their service year and prepare for post-service employment.

Other speakers at the event, including Mrs. Stella Nweke (Assistant Director, SAED), Mrs. Thomas Iraboh (National Directorate of Employment), and Mrs. Iyanuoluwa (Federal Ministry of Labour and Employment), shared insights on vocational training, job creation initiatives, and workplace safety regulations.

Engineer George Richard, the oldest SAED trainer, advised corps members on job security and interview skills, emphasizing the importance of unique skills and international language proficiency.

In her closing remarks, Mrs. Salmwang urged corps members to avoid drug abuse, focus on personal development, and contribute positively to society.
In a related development, the Institute of professional Entrepreneurship Development successfully concluded its three month training program, graduating twenty corps members who were awarded certificates in various professionals courses ,including project Management, Facility Management, Human Resources Management, and Entrepreneurship Development, equipping them with valuable skills for their future endeavors.

LAGOS CORPS MEMBER EMPOWERS STUDENTS THROUGH GOAL 4 AND 10 OF SDGs

A corps member of Oshodi/Isolo Local Government Area, Favour Obeto, has made a remarkable impact by donating 55 brand new school uniforms, three large 4x8 white marker boards, and a 15 inch public address system (PAS) to students of Oshodi Comprehensive Senior and Junior High School, Oshodi, Lagos.

Obeto Favour with code number LA/24B/9036, member of the SDGs Special CDS group, said the project was inspired by Sustainable Development Goals 4 and 10, which promote Quality Education and Reduced Inequality.

The corps member who is currently serving at Mopson Pharmaceutical Limited chose to carry out the project at Oshodi Comprehensive Senior and Junior Schools after a personal encounter with some of the students. She noted that despite wearing tattered uniforms, the students displayed a strong eagerness to learn. This moved her to conduct a needs assessment and take practical steps to support their education.

She acknowledged the support of donors who made the project possible, including BEMJ International Educational Services, Abraham Ilukhor Foundation, Jehokel Construction Company, Mr. Gift A. Oboh, Mr. Innocent Omozokpia, and Mopson Pharmaceutical Limited.

Speaking at the event, the Lagos State Coordinator, Mrs. Christianah Salmwang, represented by the Assistant Director, Community Development Service (CDS), Mrs. Grace Oso emphasized that CDS is one of the four Cardinal programs of the scheme, through which corps members are expected to give back to their host communities. She commended Favour for her commitment to the ideals of the scheme and the outstanding effort to leave a legacy worthy of emulation. She therefore called on the Corps members present to draw inspiration from Favour by positively impacting their host community.

The Principal of Oshodi Comprehensive Senior High School, Mr. Oyemakin Felix, expressed deep appreciation for Favour‚Äôs commitment to the success of the project. He also acknowledged the efforts of the Lagos State Government in improving the standard of education.

One of the sponsors, Mr. Jeremiah Etu, also commended Favour for her previous initiative ‚ÄúPad a Girl‚Äù project in Edo State, and thanked the NYSC for encouraging community development efforts like hers.

Mrs. Mojisola Amodu, SDGs Schedule Officer, commended Favour Obeto for her resilience and determination in executing the project. She lauded Obeto's dedication, stating it reflects the true spirit of the Sustainable Development Goals.

The event was graced by the presence of the Assistant Director CDS, Mrs. Grace Oso; the Principals of both the Senior and Junior sections of Oshodi Comprehensive High School; the Zonal Inspector,Ikeja zone ,Mrs. Yewande Abimbola; the SDG Schedule Officer, Mrs. Mojisola Amodu; the NYSC Local Government Inspector for Oshodi/Isolo, Mrs. Oyerinde Omolara,NYSC officials,teachers, and parents.

Medical CDS Sensitises Otan Ayegbaju Students on Hygiene and Reproductive Health

The Medical CDS group of Boluwaduro Local Government carried out a  Sensitisation programme on personal hygiene, menstrual health, and sex education at Muslim Comprehensive High School, Otan Ayegbaju. The event, held on Thursday, aimed to raise awareness among students about healthy living, reproductive health, and responsible behavior.

The programme targeted junior and senior secondary students, with topics tailored to their age groups. Corps Member Chiedu Faith spoke to students in JSS 1‚Äì3 on the importance of personal hygiene, stressing daily cleanliness, grooming habits, and the prevention of hygiene-related illnesses. For senior students, Corps Member Edobor Alexandra  delivered a session on sex education, covering puberty, sexually transmitted infections, unplanned pregnancies, and the value of abstinence and consent.

Senior female students also received guidance on menstrual hygiene from Ocheje Best, who educated them on the menstrual cycle, sanitary practices, and overcoming stigma around menstruation. Additionally, Mustapha Ameerah gave a moral talk, encouraging students to uphold discipline, self-respect, and good conduct.

To ensure the sustainability of the initiative, the school principal and health personnel were actively involved in both planning and delivery. Hygiene and sex education materials were handed over to the school, with plans to incorporate the topics into Health Club activities and guidance sessions for continuous learning and impact.

The programme concluded with an interactive Q&A session, during which students‚Äô questions were addressed. The Medical CDS team emphasised that hygiene is dignity, education is protection, and there is no shame in seeking help about one's health. The Sensitisation effort successfully empowered students with the knowledge to make informed, healthy, and respectful choices.

**Attention Batch B, 2025 PCMs:**

Lastly, for registered PCMs who have been deployed but did not report to camp: your data will be transferred to Batch B at the appropriate time, and it is hoped that you will be deployed with Batch B. Please remember that revalidation is automatic; however, deployment is determined by NYSC policy.

STATE COORDINATOR NYSC LAGOS, URGES OFFICIALS TO BE EMPATHETIC TOWARDS CORPS MEMBERS

As the 2025 Batch "B" Stream I Orientation Course is set to begin, State Coordinator NYSC Lagos, Mrs Christiana Salmwang, has in a meeting of NYSC officials and Collaborating Agencies at the NYSC Lagos State Secretariat, called on officials to be empathetic to corps members.

The State Coordinator, who appreciated the officials for their display of professionalism which led to the seamless implementation of the last Orientation Course, urged officials to avoid complacency as no one Orientation Course is the same. She called for discipline among officials, and mature engagement of NYSC stakeholders for continuous robust relationship as synergy is integral in pursuing a successful Course.

She also called for the avoidance of corporal punishment while dealing with corps members.

Speaking during the meeting, the Camp Director for the 2025 Batch "B" Stream I Orientation Course, Mrs Itohan Ehimwenma, who described her assignment as the Camp Director as a honourable one, called on officials to follow the path of integrity. She said officials must be seen to walk their talk. She appealed for cooperation and support of officials for the successful implementation of the Orientation Course.
Declaring the theme of the course as "Excellence; pathway to success," she noted that officials in the State is known for being at their best. She charged them to be better than they have always been.

Also, speaking during the meeting, the Camp Commandant designate for the Orientation Course, Captain VC Uchefuna, who described the NYSC as a beautiful programme which made him a better person, pledged that there won't be inter-agency rivalry, and that collaborating agencies will be disciplined, emphasizing that the rules of engagement will be kept.

Meanwhile, in a separate development, while holding general meeting with members of NYSC officials, the State Coordinator, harped on commitment and attendance in all programmes during the course. 
She encouraged them to be united and be supportive of themselves. 

Echoing the comments of the State Coordinator, the Camp Director encouraged officials to do their best and that the young ones will be looking up to them for guidance and as such must act with integrity. 

Also, the Deputy Camp Director, Mr Wasiu Adebayo, called on officials to operate in unity and attend to the Orientation programme in cooperation. 

Meanwhile, the 2025 Batch "B" Stream I Orientation Course commences on the Wednesday 30th of July, and ends on the 19th of August, 2025.

NYSC WHAT NEXT AFRICA CDS GROUP EMPOWERS ILE-OLUJI STUDENTS THROUGH SKILLS ACQUISITION PROGRAM

In a remarkable effort to promote youth empowerment and community development, the NYSC What Next Africa Community Development Service (CDS) Group has successfully organized a dynamic skills acquisition program for students in Ileoluji, Ondo State. The event, which took place at the Bola Ahmed Tinubu Entrepreneurship Center, drew over 100 enthusiastic participants, primarily secondary school students, eager to broaden their horizons and improve their future employability.

The initiative was spearheaded by Corps Members Miss Oma-Wilkie Temisan Utieyin (OD/24B/3262) and Adewumi Idowu Paul (OD/24B/3457), with full support from the What Next Africa CDS Group. Recognizing the urgent need for skill-based education in the community, the group conceptualized and executed the project to address this gap.

The program featured a series of practical workshops designed to impart both entrepreneurial and technical skills vital for personal and professional growth. Areas covered included digital marketing, tailoring, make up, computer literacy, and baking. Each session was facilitated by experienced professionals who provided hands-on training and mentorship, ensuring that participants gained practical, actionable knowledge they could immediately apply.

Speaking at the event, one of the facilitators emphasized the importance of empowering young people with relevant skills in today‚Äôs fast-changing economic landscape: ‚ÄúEducation goes beyond the classroom. Programs like this give students a head start by teaching them how to be self-reliant, creative, and digitally aware.‚Äù

This initiative reflects the NYSC What Next Africa CDS Group‚Äôs unwavering commitment to empowering youth and supporting sustainable development at the grassroots level. By equipping young minds with employable skills, the group is helping to bridge the gap between education and real-world opportunities, particularly in underserved communities.

The program also aligns with the broader objectives of the NYSC scheme, which seeks to foster national unity and development through youth-driven projects and civic engagement.

According to the CDS group coordinator, ‚ÄúOur goal is to create a ripple effect of transformation. By empowering just one young person with a skill, we are setting the stage for broader social and economic impact.‚Äù

We would like to take this opportunity to express our appreciation to Mrs. Carolina Jaiyeola A., our LGI, who has been our guide and mentor. We would also like to thank HRM Oba (Dr.) Oluwole Olufaderin Adetimehin, FIIN, FCIB, Jimoko II, Jegun of Ile-Oluji for his royal endorsement and sponsorship, as well as the director and staff of the Bola Ahmed Tinubu Entrepreneurship Center for their collaboration and support in providing a conducive venue.

With initiatives like this, the NYSC What Next Africa CDS Group is building a future where Nigerian youth are not just job seekers, but solution providers, innovators, and leaders of change.

Ife South Corps Members Empower Girls Through Football, Extend Compassion Through Charity

Corps Members serving in Ife South Local Government Area of Osun State have demonstrated their commitment to community development service through two major initiatives focused on empowerment and humanitarian service.

On Tuesday, July 8, 2025, the final match of an Inter-School Female Football Competition was held at Olode Community. The tournament, which began on June 23, 2025, featured seven secondary schools and was spearheaded by Corps Members Akintunde Elijah Olanrewaju (OS/24B/5021) and Adepoju Mutiu Babalola (OS/24B/5029). 

Designed as a Community Development Service (CDS) project, the initiative aimed to provide a platform for female students to display their athletic talents while fostering teamwork and confidence. The event was graced by the Olu of Olode, Oba Yekeen Omisore, alongside community chiefs, school representatives, and residents.

In a separate outreach, Corps Members in Ifetedo community carried out a Charity Service exercise targeting underprivileged individuals. Initiated by Friday Raphael Ukwumaka (OS/24C/2582) and Nkemjika Chiamaka Amarachi (OS/24B/4056), the outreach involved distributing essential food items such as rice, beans, spaghetti, and cooking oil to seven identified beneficiaries in the community. The team, supported by Onikede Waliat (OS/24C/0143) and Ogabi Tolulope (OS/24C/2543), visited each recipient at home, receiving heartfelt gratitude and prayers in return.

Following the outreach, the Corps Members paid a courtesy visit to the palace of His Royal Majesty Oba Akinola Oyetade Akinrera, Latiri I, the Olubosin of Ifetedo Kingdom, where they were warmly received by the chiefs, who lauded their compassion and community spirit.

The Corps Members have, through these projects, not only reinforced the NYSC‚Äôs core values of service and unity, but also left lasting impacts on the lives they touched.

WE SHALL KEEP SUPPORTING NYSC - NASARAWA ACTING GOVERNOR

The Acting Governor of Nasarawa State, Dr Emmanuel Akabe has reiterated the State's resolve to sustain it's support for the National Youth Service Corps.

He stated this while playing host to the Director General of NYSC, Brigadier General Olakunle Nafiu, when the latter paid him a courtesy visit at Government House in Lafia, the State Capital.

Akabe said the administration of Governor Abdullahi Sule holds NYSC in high esteem, considering Corps Members' role in fostering national unity, integration and all-round development.

Dr Akabe used the occasion to announce that the State Government planned to give an official vehicle to the NYSC North-Central II Area Office, Lafia, to enable seamless operations of the Office.

He commended both the Director, NYSC North-Central II Area Office, Mrs Grace Ogbuogebe and the Nasarawa State Coordinator, Hajiya Salamatu Muhammad for their resilience in pursuing the Scheme's interests in the Zone and the State. Akabe described Muhammad as "two men in one woman" owing to her proactiveness in addressing the issues of security and welfare of Corps Members in the State.

Dr Akabe, who recounted his experience as a Corps Member in 1985 with nostalgia, said most of his close friends across Nigeria are people he met during his service year in Enugu the capital of the now defunct Anambra State.

While expressing appreciation to the Management of NYSC for choosing Lafia as the venue for 2025 Batch 'B' Pre-Orientation Workshop, the Acting Governor enjoined the participants to take some time to experience and enjoy the serene environment and hospitality of the State.

The Director General of NYSC informed his host that members of NYSC top management, State Coordinators, Camp Directors and Camp Commandant designates, as well as representatives of the Police, Nigeria Security and Civil Defence Corps, Nigeria Red Cross Society, Federal Fire Service, Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, National Drug Law Enforcement Agency, National Health Insurance Authority and Citizenship and Leadership Training Centre had converged in Lafia for the Workshop.

He explained that the workshop was an avenue through which the stakeholders reviewed previous Orientation Exercise, with a view to charting a new course for the forthcoming exercise.

The NYSC helmsman lauded the State Government for its consistent support to NYSC's general operations. He expressed appreciation for the facelift being given to the Magaji Dan-Yamusa Nasarawa State NYSC Permanent Orientation Camp in Keffi, especially the ongoing construction of a gigantic multipurpose hall.

Brigadier General Nafiu reaffirmed NYSC's commitment to nation building, through the deployment of skilled graduates to offer free services to all sectors of the nation's economy.

"We inject a minimum of 1,000 teachers to the education sector of every State of the Federation and the Federal Capital Territory during each of the six streams of service year, annually. We equally distribute medical personnel, engineers, lawyers, accountants, psychologists and all other categories of professionals in like manner, and we are poised to do more", he added.

NYSC ENUGU STATE COORDINATOR PAYS COURTESY VISIT  TO GOVERNOR PETER MBAH 

The Enugu State Coordinator of the National Youth Service Corps (NYSC), Mrs. Oluwakemi Awolola, accompanied by some members of staff, paid a courtesy visit to the Executive Governor of Enugu State, His Excellency Dr. Peter Ndubuisi Mba, on July 10, 2025, at the Government House, Enugu.

The visit commenced with a brief introduction by the Chairman of the NYSC State Governing Board and Hon. Commissioner for Youth and Sports, Barr. Lloyd Ekweremmadu. In her remarks, the State Coordinator expressed sincere appreciation to the Governor for his unwavering support for the welfare of corps members in the state. She particularly commended his administration‚Äôs recent efforts in upgrading infrastructure at the NYSC Orientation Camp in Awgu.

Mrs. Awolola further used the opportunity to present a comprehensive report on the challenges confronting the scheme in the state, with special emphasis on the deplorable condition of facilities at the orientation camp. She presented graphic images to illustrate the state of disrepair and passionately appealed for urgent intervention, describing the Governor as a visionary leader and a result-oriented administrator. She also drew attention to the corps members‚Äô monthly state allowance, which she noted was among the lowest in the country.

In response, Governor Mba acknowledged the significant contributions of NYSC to national development and lauded the scheme's legacy of service and youth empowerment. He expressed concern over the poor state of the camp facilities and immediately directed the Commissioner for Youth and Sports to commence a total renovation of the orientation camp. He assured that the state government would complete the project within three months and, in the interim, advised that the next orientation course be relocated to another venue within the state. He further noted that the renovated camp would also serve as a strategic asset during the forthcoming National Sports Festival to be hosted by Enugu State.

On the issue of corps members‚Äô welfare, the Governor announced a substantial increase in their monthly state allowance. Henceforth, regular corps members will receive ‚Ç¶20,000 monthly, while corps medical doctors will earn ‚Ç¶80,000. Pharmacists will be paid ‚Ç¶60,000, and nurses as well as other corps medical personnel will receive ‚Ç¶40,000 monthly. To ensure prompt implementation, the Governor directed that the Secretary to the State Government be immediately notified.

Governor Mba reaffirmed his administration's commitment to strengthening collaboration with the NYSC, particularly in the area of healthcare delivery. He further pledged to provide an official vehicle for the NYSC State Coordinator, upon learning that the scheme currently operates without one in the state.

In her closing remarks, Mrs. Awolola expressed profound gratitude to the Governor for his unprecedented support and generosity. She assured him of NYSC‚Äôs continued commitment to supporting the developmental agenda of the state and pledged to promptly convey the Governor‚Äôs goodwill message to the Director-General of NYSC, Brigadier General O.O. Nafiu.

The visit was rounded off with a group photograph to commemorate the occasion.

Medical, Charity CDS Conduct Genotype and Health Awareness Outreach for Students in Ikire

The Medical and Charity CDS groups of Irewole LGA organised a Community Health Awareness and Genotype Testing Outreach on Monday, at Ibran Hotel and Event Centre, Itaakun. The project targeted secondary school students aged 14‚Äì20, focusing on educating them about genotype, blood group, and marriage compatibility.

Ahead of the event, blood samples were collected from interested students across nine schools between July 10 and 11, with parental consent. These samples were analysed at St. Jude Hospital, Ikire. 

The President of the Medical CDS, Okafor Livinus, in his welcome address, highlighted the importance of early awareness of genotype and blood group in health and relationship decisions. Three insightful presentations were delivered by Egbon Orobosa Krystal, Okafor Livinus, and Dr. Habeeb Bolakole Sulaiman on topics ranging from genotype inheritance to blood group relevance and compatibility in relationships. The students engaged actively, asking questions and sharing experiences.

After the educational sessions, students collected their test results and received personalised counselling from medical Corps Members. Light refreshments were served, and appreciation was extended to participating schools and supporters, notably the CEO of Ibran Hotel and NYSC officials.

In total, 200 students were tested and empowered with life-changing health knowledge. The project was praised by teachers, students, and NYSC officials, with calls for future collaborations. The programme had in attendance the Zonal Inspector Ife Zone, Mr Owoseni Akin, the Local Government Inspector Irewole, Mr Atere Olalekan, among others.

As the 2025 Batch B Stream 1 Orientation Course draws near, the NYSC Osun State Coordinator, Mr. Agbor Ndoma Obim, has declared that discipline should be the watchword, urging staff and collaborating agencies to demonstrate greater commitment, integrity, professionalism, and teamwork throughout the exercise.

Agbor made the call during a series of strategic meetings held separately with Heads of Assignments, collaborating agencies, and NYSC staff today at the State Secretariat in Osogbo. This is in preparation for the Orientation Course set to commence on Tuesday, 30th of July, 2025, at the NYSC Permanent Orientation Camp, Ede.

The Coordinator highlighted the importance of upholding the integrity of the NYSC Scheme despite external pressures, warning against acts of extortion, over-socialisation, and poor work ethics. 

He condemned the increasing disregard for morning meditation by Officials and warned that nonattendance will be duly punished in accordance with the Scheme's Orientation guidelines and code of conduct. 

He called for the reorientation of Corps Members returning from relocation or on exeat to ensure they are properly integrated into the programme. 

He emphasised mentorship, diplomacy in handling Corps Members‚Äô issues, and the need for State Governments to improve stipends for Corps Members especially those posted to government schools in order to boost the morale and encourage Corps Members to settle down in their places of Primary Assignments rather than seeking reposting to the capital.

In her brief, the Camp Director, Mrs. Otunla Ronke, echoed the Coordinator‚Äôs message and charged staff to carry out their responsibilities more effectively.

She cautioned against holding any parallel programmes during lectures and SAED and announced that Corps Members would be co-opted into Camp market surveillance to assist in monitoring Camp market activities. This, according to her, is to ensure inclusivity and to enhance positive feedback from the Corps Members.

The Camp Commandant, Capt. SP. Yerima, in his brief called on all security and collaborating agencies to maintain a high standard of professionalism and ensure discipline and safety remain collective priorities.

During the staff meeting, Heads of Branches, Units, and Assignments took turns to brief the house on the progress recorded in their respective offices, outlining expectations and detailing the level of preparedness ahead of the forthcoming Orientation Course.

He assured that the supplies would be judiciously used and encouraged other organisations to support NYSC in similar impactful ways.

NYSC LAGOS OFFICIALS RECEIVE TRAINING ON ONLINE DECLARATION OF ASSETS

In a bid to attenuate corrupt practices and ensure compliance with the code of conduct for public officers, officials of the Code of Conduct Bureau, have engaged officials of the NYSC at the NYSC Lagos State Secretariat, on online declaration of assets.

The officials, Dr Ayodeji Fatehinse and Mr Emmanuel Sonuga, enlightened the officials on the need to establish a high standard of morality in the conduct of government business and to ensure that the actions and behaviours of public officers conform to the highest standards of public morality and accountability. They highlighted conflict of interest with duties, restriction on specified officers, prohibition of foreign accounts, retired public officers, gifts or benefits to certain public officers, bribery of public officers, abuse of power, membership of societies, declaration of assets, allegation of breach of code and conflict of interests etc.

They concluded that the code of conduct for public officers should serve as a mechanism for continuous self-assessment by public officers in their efforts to meeting with public expectations, scrutiny and evaluation. They urged officials to promote integrity, anticipate public perception, try to live within their means, have a heightened awareness of statutory provisions and regulations and develop an attitude of compliance, ask for adequate material resources to carry out their assignments among many others.

While giving her remarks during the programme, the State Coordinator NYSC Lagos, Mrs Christiana Salmwang, appreciated the Management of the National Youth Service Corps, for approving such programme for the enlightenment of officials of the scheme. She equally appreciated officials of the Code of Conduct Bereau for the sensitization on the procedural engagement to be given to the declaration of assets. She appealed to them for more simplification of the processes of declaration of assets and co-opting of younger officers into the education process of asset declaration.

*Tips for camping üëá*

1. Posting to orientation camp is random. Except for married female PCM that will be posted to their husband state of residence. Others will be posted to the 37 different camp randomly in no orderly manner.

2. ‚Å†Prepare yourself medically, mentally and physically for the stress ahead. Get enough rest to cushion for the restless camp schedule.

3. ‚Å†Feeding in camp is free. 3 meals which consist of breakfast, lunch and Dinner.

4. ‚Å†You can get extra food in the Mami market at personal cost. You can also get other important items in camp.

5. ‚Å†Get all of your kits at home if you are not financially prepared or bouyant.

6. ‚Å†NYSC camp is a paramilitary camp and you will be treated with utmost respect, but when going to camp, don‚Äôt go with hard drugs, sharp object or heavy electronic gadgets including personal laptop.

7. ‚Å†Ladies should note that their monthly period will most likely surface while in camp, prepare with enough menstrual kits while going to camp.

8. ‚Å†Call up letter is expected out 3 days to camp activities . Be patient and wait. 

9. ‚Å†Prepare like you are going to the farthest distance from you, while you keep your mind open to possibility of getting the state close by too.

10. ‚Å†If you are not ready to camp yet but you registered, simply be strong and attend , maybe you seek relocation later because with the new policy and queue might be till 2026

11. ‚Å†Remember that Original statement of result or Certificate is compulsory. If you don‚Äôt have original copy, stay back till you get it.

12. The rubber shoe you are going to buy, make sure it‚Äôs oversize. If you are size 30, buy size 32

13. Due to the strictness in camp, if you are not very strong for camp activities, get a letter of exemption from parade and other strenuous activities 

14. Pregnant and nursing mothers are not allowed to participate in camp activities, therefore they go home after registration.

15. You will wear mostly white shirts and short, bright colored underwear are not advised, black underwear are the best especially for ladies.

16. Parades are compulsory for everyone except you are in First Aid ‚õëÔ∏è crew or in special camp assignment like clinic.

17. Get malaria and stress relieving painkillers before going to camp.

18. Take a mosquito net along with you to reduce chances of getting malaria while in camp.

19. There are restrictions in camp hostels, guys can‚Äôt go to female hostels and ladies can't.

The National Youth Service Corps has promised stronger synergy with its critical partners and other stakeholders in the conduct of the Orientation Course and other aspects of the Scheme's operations. 

The Director General of National Youth Service Corps, Brigadier General Olakunle Nafiu stated this today at the Opening Ceremony of the 2025 Batch 'B' Pre-Orientation Workshop held in Lafia, Nasarawa State.

The DG, who said the Pre-Orientation Course workshop served as a platform for NYSC Management and other key stakeholders in the Orientation activities to review the previous Orientation Course added that the goal was to improve NYSC operations for future sessions. 

General Nafiu stated further that, the periodic conduct of Pre-Orientation  workshop was borne out of NYSC Management‚Äôs determination to ensure the continuous improvement of the Orientation Course content with a view to equipping the Corps Members adequately for the enormous task of nation building. 

He said the Orientation Course must continue to serve as a platform for instilling discipline, patriotism, and unity‚Äîvalues that were non-negotiable in nation-building, amid distractions and competing interests.

Nasarawa State Governor, Engr. Abdullahi Sule while declaring open the workshop, with the theme, "Maintaining the Integrity of the Orientation Course in the face of Competing Interests", pledged continued support to the NYSC.

He said since the inception of National Youth Service Corps in 1973, the Scheme has been playing a pivotal role in national development, while commending its commendable efforts in community development, healthcare services, public policy awareness, educational interventions, and participation in national exercises such as elections, census among others, which have earned Nigeria accolades both domestically and internationally. 

He described NYSC as a cornerstone of collective aspirations, that needed the support of all stakeholders. A

The Governor, who was represented by his Deputy, Dr Emmanuel Akabe  appreciated the invaluable contributions of Corps Members to the State in healthcare delivery, community development projects, environmental sanitation, and socio-economic services.

"It is crucial that we continue to provide unwavering support to the Scheme, building upon its myriad of achievements across all sectors of national economic development. 

We are dedicated to infrastructural development, creating an enabling environment for our youths to thrive", the Governor said. 

He urged the Scheme to innovate further on cementing its roles in national development and earning greater admiration from Nigerians.

The Director, Planning Research and Statistics, Dr Ahmed Wada Ikaka in his introductory address said the Orientation Camp being the first point of contact for the Corps Members creates a lasting impression on them, hence, the need to make it a worthwhile and impactful lifetime experience.

NYSC RECOMMITS TO TECH-DRIVEN MOBILISATION PROCESS - DG

The Director General of National Youth Service Corps, Brigadier General Olakunle Nafiu has said the Scheme would continue to deplore more ICT tools to enhance its mobilisation process.

He said the NYSC would also continue to train its mobilization officers on data verification, error resolution and emergency response, cybersecurity software training for staff handling sensitive data, among others.

He said this was necessary as the number of threats and attacks on the Scheme's mobilization system increased daily. 

General Nafiu stated this today in his keynote address at the 2025 Batch 'B' Pre-Mobilization Workshop with the theme; "Strengthening the NYSC Mobilisation Process through Improved Technology and Collaboration with Stakeholders, held in Abuja.

He disclosed further that
reforming the NYSC mobilization process had become necessary in the present dispensation, because the society was evolving and the Scheme must adjust its strategies to match current realities. 

"We at NYSC recognize that by leveraging technology, forging stronger partnerships, investing in infrastructure, and deploying relevant skills, we can boost efficiency, enhance the experience of both prospective and serving Corps Members, and maintain the Scheme‚Äôs role in national development.

I therefore urge all our partners and collaborating agencies, particularly the Corps-producing institutions, to speed up the process of technological update to an acceptable level that makes collaboration and partnership seamless and more functional.

Let us not betray that trust. Let us jointly commit to prioritizing integrity over expediency, innovating for efficiency, and collaborating for national progress.
We are on the threshold of transformation. With technology as our tool and collaboration as our compass, we will build a mobilization system that is secure, smart, and truly service-driven", General Nafiu said.

The Director General also said although the Scheme had attempted to update its mobilization process in line with changes in Nigeria‚Äôs educational policy and environment, it still faced several challenges, including; mismatched data from institutions, uploads of unqualified or part-time graduates, technical glitches that result in frustrating delays, attempts at falsification of records among others.

The Director, Corps Mobilization, Alhaji Mohammed Abubakar said the workshop was an avenue for bringing the NYSC, Corps Producing Institutions and other key stakeholders to brainstorm and improve on the Scheme's mobilization efforts.

He said though the Scheme had made remarkable progress as a result of collaboration, but there was need to tackle fraudulent uploading of unqualified graduates.

"This process is vital for our nation's growth but it is fraught with challenges, especially with dishonest enrollments. We must therefore stay alert and be proactive", he said.

Alhaji Abubakar urged the participants to be diligent in their assignments with high integrity and ensure they upload accurate information of their prospective Members.
